Key Arguments: The bill undermines freedom of speech, a fundamental democratic principle.
It creates a two-tier system privileging politicians, journalists, and educational institutions over regular citizens.
Excessive fines will lead to overly restrictive speech policies by digital services.
Determining truth is complex and historically, authoritative figures have been proven wrong.
The bill promotes censorship rather than open discourse.
Industry codes may become anti-competitive, favoring large digital services over smaller competitors.
The extraterritorial application of the bill is unreasonable and could isolate Australia from the global internet community.
Delegating legislative power to private entities may violate constitutional freedoms.
Notable Quotes: The existence of this bill signifies a lack of respect for the fundamental freedom of speech that is essential to our democracy.
The excessive fines imposed by this bill will undoubtedly lead digital services to adopt a more restrictive approach to speech than currently exists.
The proposed industry codes, created by bodies influenced by industry giants, are likely to become 'anti-competitive wedges' that block smaller competitors from entering the market.
The extraterritorial application of this bill is an unreasonable overreach of Australian law onto foreign entities.
